page.title: 04FARMING IN SHROTON
page.content: THERE ARE 5 FARMS WITH LAND IN OUR 12 KM. SQUARE,{DAIRYING}IS TYPICAL ON THE WET CLAY SOILS BUT INCREASINGLY CROPS ARE GROWN ESPECIALLY ON THE UPLANDS WHERE SOILS ARE FERTILIZED TO PRODUCE QUALITY{CROPS}OF WHEAT, BARLEY AND THE NEWER OIL SEED RAPE (BRIGHT YELLOW FIELDS IN SPRING) AND DURUM WHEAT GROWN FOR PASTA. STEEPER SLOPES ARE LEFT TO WOODS OR{SHEEP GRAZING.}HEDGES AND TREES HAVE BEEN LOST TO BIG FIELDS AND DUTCH ELM DISEASE. FARMERS SHOW CONCERN FOR THIS BY PLANTING NEW TREES THE BUSIEST TIME IS JUL-AUG WHEN HARVESTING IS DONE, CLOSELY FOLLOWED BY PLOUGHING AND SOWING NEXT YEAR'S CROPS. IN AUTUMN TOO MOST COWS HAVE THEIR CALVES. JAN-MAY IS MAINLY FERTILISING AND SPRAYING TO PREVENT PESTS AND DISEASES. SILAGE IS CUT DURING MAY-JUNE AND PUT INTO CLAMPS NEXT TO THE DAIRY FOR WINTER FEED.
